content: <xml>   <records>        <record>       <contributors>         <authors>           <author>Zeldes, Amir</author>           <author>Ritz, Julia</author>           <author>Romary, Laurent</author>           <author>Leser, Ulf</author>           <author>Zipser, Florian</author>         </authors>       </contributors>       <titles>         <title>Pepper: Handling a multiverse of formats</title>         <secondary-title/>       </titles>       <doi>10.5281/zenodo.15638</doi>       <pages/>       <volume/>       <number/>       <keywords>         <keyword>Salt</keyword>         <keyword>Pepper</keyword>         <keyword>conversion</keyword>         <keyword>linguistic data</keyword>         <keyword>format</keyword>         <keyword>conversion framework</keyword>         <keyword>EXMARaLDA</keyword>         <keyword>TIGER XML</keyword>         <keyword>corpus</keyword>         <keyword>converter</keyword>         <keyword>plugin</keyword>       </keywords>       <dates>         <year>2011</year>         <pub-dates>           <date>2011-02-24</date>         </pub-dates>       </dates>       <abstract><p>With the rising importance of empirical data in many fields of linguistic research, we see an<br />     increase not only in the amount of electronically available corpora, but also in the number of<br />     tools used to make this data accessible, processable and searchable. Most of these tools have<br />     been developed in the course of specific linguistic projects and therefore can only handle a<br />     certain kinds of linguistic information, such as syntactic-structures (e.g. TIGERSearch, Lezius<br />     2002), or dialogue-structures (e.g. EXMARaLDA, Schmidt 2004) etc. At the same time, each<br />     tool uses its own, proprietary format for representing the text and its annotations. Such<br />     formats are optimized for a specific kind of analysis and the performance of a specific<br />     processing tool. Consequently they cannot easily be mapped onto each other. This impedes<br />     those linguistic research questions which pre-suppose a global view on data, i.e., which<br />     require the option to correlate, query and analyze several kinds of linguistic annotations at<br />     once.<br />     We present Pepper, a modularized converter framework addressing the problem that a<br />     linguistic researcher may be limited to a small set of questions due to the tool(s) he or she<br />     uses. Pepper is based on the meta-model Salt (Zipser &amp; Romary 2010) and offers the<br />     possibility of converting data from n formats into m formats with a minimal number of<br />     necessary mappings. The pluggable architecture of Pepper allows the injection of new formats<br />     into the framework. Pepper has no restrictions on the underlying techniques used in<br />     representing these formats (e.g. XML, tabular-formats, bracketing-formats or mixtures<br />     thereof).</p></abstract>     </record>      </records> </xml>
